_exec_summary.SummaryText:
THE ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES 



Policies for Accident Release Prevention and Emergency Response are included in Freeport-McMoran Sierrita's (FMS) General Safety and Environmental Handbook. Each employee is provided with a copy of the Handbook. FMS is committed to the implementation of these policies, which has resulted in there being no chlorine related accident in the last 5 years. 



It must be stated that FMS has been recognized for its excellent record of safety.  In 1993, 1997, 1999, and 2001, FMS received the Sentinels of Safety Award.  This Award is co-sponsored by the American Mining Congress and MSHA, and is recognized as the most prestigious award for safety in the mining industry.   



YOUR FACILITY AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED



FMS  operates a copper and molybdenum mining and concentrating facility located approximately seven miles west of Green Valley, Arizona. Ore containing low-grade copper and molybdenum is excavated, crushed, conveyed, milled and treated with chemicals to produce copper and molybdenum  concentrates. Copper concentrates are shipped to a smelter for further processing. The molybdenum  concentrate contains a small percentage of copper. It is first treated with ferric chloride for removal of copper and  then roasted to yield molybdenum trioxide which is packaged for distribution. 



The regulated substance handled at the facility is chlorine. It is used for the regeneration of ferric chloride. 



THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



The Accidental Release Prevention Program is designed in accordance with 40 CFR Part 68. It includes off-site consequence analysis, safety information, hazard review, standard operating procedures, training, inspections and maintenance, compliance audits, management systems and emergency response program.  



Chlorine specific prevention steps include: (1) chlorine sensors located around the perimeter of

the chlorinator area for identifying the presence of chlorine; (2) check valves on chlorine railcars which  cut off the chlorine supply in case of emergency; (3) remote video monitoring system in the control room; (4) absorption system to remove excess chlorine and prevent a chlorine release; (5) standard operating procedures which are in accordance with the Molybdenum Processing certified International Standards Organization (ISO) 9000 system; (6)  regular inspections and maintenance of all process, control and electrical equipment; (7) training of all personnel involved in the chlorination system; (8) hazard reviews; (9) compliance audits; and (10) site assessments by chlorine supplier.



THE FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no accidents for the last five years. 



THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



FMS has an Emergency Response Plan (ERP) Plan to minimize impacts to human health and safety in case of a release. The ERP includes contact information of key people, coordination arrangements with external agencies, personal protective equipment, medical response team, evacuation routes, emergency notification procedures, emergency communication systems, emergency response team, and post-emergency decontamination procedures.         



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



Planned changes to improve safety include modifications to the existing process control system and implementation of a HazOps study for the chlorination system.
